title: Who will be elected governor of Montana in 2020?
preds: Competition race, state leaning towards Trump.

"we're shifting one contest in the Republican direction: The seat being given up by Montana's Democratic Gov. Steve Bullock, who is running in a high-profile U.S. Senate race. We're moving that contest from Toss-up to Lean Republican. The Montana race remains highly competitive, but the state's Republican leanings are proving challenging for the Democratic nominee, Lt. Gov. Mike Cooney, to overcome. His opponent, Greg Gianforte, is the state's sole U.S. House member. Gianforte has led Cooney in every public poll this year, usually by margins in the low-to-mid single digits. Cooney needs to hope for a tailwind from Bullock's campaign and a large turnout from the state's heavy use of mail balloting this year." https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-10-29/analysis-republicans-maintain-edge-in-governor-races
Polls have tightened and even Bullock shows signs he could win the Senate seat. Republicans still have the edge here.

Recent polls show the Republican candidate continues to have a solid lead. Not enough good polls to move the needle too much but worth an update of a couple of points. [1] [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/montana/
Red state, Rep lead over recent months, unlikely to change between now and the election.

"Montana is a red state, but the Democrats have held the governorship since winning the 2004 election. Now, Bullock's departure is leaving the seat open. U.S. Rep. Greg Gianforte won the GOP primary. The upside for Republicans is that Gianforte is a former tech CEO with deep pockets. The downside is that Gianforte is best known for assaulting a reporter, which resulted in a sentence of 40 hours of community service and 20 hours of anger management classes. Meanwhile, the Democratic nominee, Lt. Gov. Mike Cooney, is well-liked and has a long resume in state politics, including service as secretary of state and state senator. But that opens the door for Cooney to be attacked as a career politician.  The latest independent poll, by the New York Times and Siena College, had Gianforte leading, 45% to 39%, with Libertarian Lyman Bishop receiving 4%. That follows a period of strong fundraising and aggressive campaigning by Cooney, and a risk-averse strategy by Gianforte. For Cooney to get all the way to 50% in a conservative state – and in a presidential election year in which a Supreme Court seat is at stake – will be challenging. The race is probably Gianforte’s to lose, but it’s close enough for us to keep it in the Tossup category for now." https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-10-13/analysis-republicans-look-poised-to-maintain-edge-in-governors-mansions
Somehow the guy who body slammed a reporter is about to be governor. Republicans have no shame.
Best polls show Republican candidate with a growing lead. [1] [1] https://int.nyt.com/data/documenttools/mt-crosstabs/4da3e297acefb561/full.pdf
Historically, Montana is a red state. Cooney is trailing in in the major polls (Siena, Emerson College). Don't see him gaining any more ground here.
Gianforte again in the lead with the latest Siena College polling by 6 points in a historically red state. Difficult to see a clear path to victory for Cooney this election cycle.

From a Cook Political report update out today: "The only true Toss Up is in the Montana open-seat contest, and this represents Republicans' best — and perhaps only — shot at flipping a governor's mansion. Polling shows GOP Rep. Greg Gianforte and Democratic Lt. Gov. Mike Cooney in a close race that will probably stay knotted up to Election Day, with Gianforte hitting Cooney for his decades in politics while Cooney is slamming Gianforte's business record."
The guy running for Governor once body slammed a reporter. How is he winning?
Gianforte jumps back to an 9 point lead in recent polling. Montana is historically Republican.
I believe it will be a win for the Democratic party. Its a belief that they are a hands-off party that would appeal to the constituents of Montana.
They’ll want steady leadership!  They’ll get it with the Dem’s

Monday's Emerson College poll showed Gianforte had widened her lead to +9, outside the margin of error for most studies. Montana is traditionally Republican (it has gone Red in 11 of the last 12 general elections), so a lead like this is unlikely to diminish before the election. Large public events or scandals could sway the voters, but with Montana trending downward in COVID cases, there is little chance of this occurring in so short a time span.
the Republican has maintained a 4-9 point lead in recent polls.
Dem has had a strong hold on Gov office even though the legislature is republican.  So close that I expect nothing to  change
Montana is a VERY red state and it takes a remarkable candidate to overcome that. Tester is one, barely. Bullock has been one, and even he's behind in the Senate race. Gianforte is strong favourite.
Lots of liberal transplants to Montana.

I will most likely update this as we get closer to the election, but as of right now these 2 are very close. If Republican turnout is low, which it probably will be, the Dem candidate has a good chance of winning.

Recent polls have the Republican Gianforte up by 3-4 percentage points, but they also show his opponent, Cooney, gaining quickly. The current state of things suggest that they are neck and neck, but the momentum is in Cooney's favor. Gianforte also lost a closely contested race in 2016, meaning he has name recognition that Cooney may lack despite Cooney's long track record in public service and upward trajectory within the Montana government. This, when combined with the national trends, suggests Cooney may have a slight lead.

I'm going out on a limb here, and I'm sure I'll change numbers as we get closer, but the Republican candidate is relying heavily on his "relationship with Donald Trump" and I don't think that is going to do him any favors in this particular election. The Democratic nominee is also currently holding high office, has extensive government experience, and doesn't seem to have a great deal many scandals to have to avoid. Again, I'll revisit as we get closer.
In a close race, the democratic nominee will squeak by due to a large democratic upheaval nationally.

Adjusting D up and R down. I still believe Gianforte is the favorite. However, I had not realised that, even in Montana, Cooney is not well known. His favorable/unfavorable is 27%/25% with 48%! undecided. This gives Cooney significantly more room to improve than Gianforte whose undecideds are much lower. Source: https://www.publicpolicypolling.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/MontanaPoll071220.pdf

In deciding the likelihood of either the (R) Republican or (D) Democratic Candidates winning the Montana Governorship in the 2020 Montana Gubernatorial Election I used -> 
X = X(outside) * W(outside) + X(inside) * W(inside)
W(outside) + W(inside) = 1
W(outside), W(inside) = [0 - 1.0]
X(outside), X(inside) = [0 - 100%]  Given the Republican & Democratic Dominance in Montana's Governorship I will assume that ->
Other Party = 0% Outside refers to previous Montana Governor election outcomes and Inside refers to the specific circumstances of the 2020 Montana Gubernatorial Election. Since 1953, the Montana Governorship has entered into a near perfect 4 Term Political Party Cycle with ->
1 - 1953-1969 - 4 Terms - Republican
2 - 1969-1989 - 5 Terms - Democratic
3 - 1989-2005 - 4 Terms - Republican
4 - 2005-2021 - 4 Terms - Democratic https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_governors_of_Montana   In 2020, Democrats will be attempting to achieve a 5th Governor Term, given this has only occurred once from 1953-2005 I will give ->
R(outside) = 67% = 2/3
D(outside) = 33% = 1/3 Due to both Republicans and Democrats having controlled the Governorship practically evenly since 1953 (47%, 53%) I don't attribute any special meaning that only Democrats have ever achieved a 5th Term.  Looking Inside, Montana Gubernatorial is considered a tossup with a very slight Republican leaning for 2020 ->   
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Montana_gubernatorial_election#Predictions  Averaging these predictions I get ->  
R(inside) = 54%
D(inside) = 46% In choosing the weighting between Outside and Inside, I decided that ->
W(outside) >> W(inside)   
           0.75 >> 0.25 While the Governorship is typically decided by very slim margins making the outcome difficult to forecast as expressed by Inside, I lean towards Outside given it is a Republican Leaning State (Cook PVI R+11) and the Cycle favours Republicans this election after the most recent 4 Democratic Terms. From this I calculate that ->
R = 64% = 67% * 0.75 + 54% * 0.25 
D = 36% = 33% * 0.75 + 46% * 0.25  Given these percentages are relatively mild, I will push these values more to their respective extremes ->
R = 80% = 64% * 1.25
D = 20% = 100% - 80% Given the possible slim margin of victory for the Governorship I will review this forecast in September / October and adjust if necessary. Republican Win in Montana for 2020 Governor Election = 80%
Democratic Win in Montana for 2020 Governor Election = 20%
Other Win in Montana for 2020 Governor Election = 0%
Past several elections Montana has been one of the few states to have a Democratic governor but vote red for presidential elections.
16 years is a long time, but Montanians will stick with what has worked.
Montana has had a Democratic Governor since 2005.
time of scarcity up there..need business "juice"..jobs, etc.
Bullick is reasonably well liked and the Dems have held the office since the failed Martz governorship
Montana's not a state that is in play for Biden therefor I don't think it's much of a chance that a Democrat will win again seeing as the incumbent is termed out and running for senate.
Republican state, but Dem Gov. Bullock, running for Senate, is popular.
Seems like a win for the GOP.
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/governor/mt/montana_governor_gianforte_vs_cooney-7203.html Also, to prove that I don't just pick Democrats

Latest polls have R candidate up by 3 to 4 points: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/montana/ Trump is currently leading polls by 9 points in the state.  Trump won the state by 20 points in 2016. The state has had a D governor since 2005.
"B" rated July 13 poll by Public Policy Polling puts Gianforte in the lead by 4 points among voters.[1] [1]https://www.publicpolicypolling.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/MontanaPoll071220.pdf

Gianforte is up slightly (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/governor/mt/montana_governor_gianforte_vs_cooney-7203.html), but Trump is up by nearly 10 points (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/mt/montana_trump_vs_biden-7196.html) It looks like a Republican victory will be coming.

Montana is a deeply republican state, although with some democratic wins over the years.  GOP candidates polling slightly ahead for Prez, senate, and governor.  I think it’s likely republican will win, but it’s not a sure thing. The course of COVID 19 may affect the race if it gets bad enough in Montana.
Polls are within MoE (slight lead to GOP) and environment is favoring Dems with souring economy and resurgence of coronavirus.

I was just in Montana, and the attack ads were blistering against the incumbent. That said, I don't know if that is indicative of local sentiments. I agree with the crowd's logic, but urge us to consider this will be closer than currently presumed.
https://www.270towin.com/2020-governor-election/
While a red state for sure, Democrats have a chance to win the governorship and the Senate here but it will be an uphill battle.
Montana is mostly rural, typically these areas vote Republican.
Accidentally switched the numbers around in my first forecast.

Montana has had a Democrat for governor since 2005. Though recent contest 2012 & 2016 have been close, I am leaning towards the democrat incumbent lieutenant governor Mike Cooney winning this election.
